[[Image:Jan Matejko, Stańczyk.jpg|thumb|377x377px|[[Stańczyk (painting)|''The Court Jester Stanczyk Receives News of the Loss of Smolensk During a Ball at Queen Bona's Court'']] ([[Jan Matejko|Matejko]],1862). Surrounded by jovial courtiers, the jester is ironically the only one troubled that the Russians are conquering Poland.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cole|first=Thomas B.|date=2009-10-21|title=<emph type="ital">The Court Jester Stanczyk (1480-1560) Receives News of the Loss of Smolensk (1514), During a Ball at Queen Bona's Court</emph>|url=https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/article-abstract/184723|journal=JAMA|language=en|volume=302|issue=15|pages=1627|doi=10.1001/jama.2009.1372|issn=0098-7484}}</ref>|alt=]]
'''The wise fool''', or '''the''' '''wisdom of the fool,''' is a form of [[Paradox (literature)|literary paradox]] in which through a narrative a character recognized as a fool comes to be seen as a beholder of wisdom.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/55800981|title="Wisdom of the Fool." New Dictionary of the History of Ideas|last=Kaiser|first=Walter|date=|publisher=Charles Scribner's Sons|others=Horowitz, Maryanne Cline, 1945-|year=|isbn=0684313774|location=[New York?]|pages=Vol. 4, 515-520|oclc=55800981}}</ref> A recognizable [[Trope (literature)|trope]] found in stories and artworks from antiquity to the twenty-first century, the wisdom of the fool often captures what [[reason]] fails to illuminate of a thing's meaning or significance; thus, the wise fool is often associated with the wisdom found through blind faith, reckless desire, hopeless romance, and wild abandon.
In turn, the wise fool is often opposed to learned or elite knowledge.<ref name=":0" /> While examples of the paradox can be found in a wide range of early world literature, from [[Greco-Roman world|Greco-Roman]] works to the oral traditions of [[Folklore|folk culture]], the paradox received unprecedented attention from authors and artists during the [[Renaissance]].<ref name=":0" /> More than [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]] for his range of clownish wise men or [[Miguel de Cervantes|Cervantes]] for his lunatic genius [[Don Quixote|Don Quijote]], sixteenth century scholar [[Erasmus]] is often credited for creating the definitive wise fool and most famous paradox in western literature<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/778636649|title=Behler, E.H. "Paradox." The Princeton Encyclopedia of Poetry and Poetics|last=|first=|date=2012|publisher=Princeton University Press|others=Greene, Roland, 1957-, Cushman, Stephen, 1956-, Cavanagh, Clare., Ramazani, Jahan, 1960-, Rouzer, Paul F., Feinsod, Harris.|year=|isbn=9780691133348|edition=4th ed|location=Princeton|pages=|oclc=778636649}}</ref> through his portrayal of Stultitia, the goddess of folly. Influential to all later fools, she shows the foolish ways of the wise and the wisdom of fools through delivering her own eulogy, ''[[In Praise of Folly|The Praise of Folly]].''<ref>{{Citation|title=Moriae encomium, that is, the praise of folly|date=2015-01-31|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1515/9781400866083-005|work=The Praise of Folly|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=9781400866083|access-date=2018-11-02}}</ref>
== Characteristics == [[File:Ivar Nilsson in Kung Lear at Dramatiska teatern 1908 - SMV - GN020.tif|thumb|[[c:Category:Ivar_Nilsson_(actor)|Ivar Nilsson]] as the Fool in a 1908 stage production of King Lear at [[Royal Dramatic Theatre|The Royal Dramatic Theatre]] in Sweden.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://calmview.statensmusikverk.se/CalmView/Record.aspx?src=CalmView.Catalog&id=GN020 |title=CalmView: Overview (Swedish Performing Arts Agency)|last=|first=|date=|website=calmview.statensmusikverk.se|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-29}}</ref>|357x357px]] In his article, ''[http://xtf.lib.virginia.edu/xtf/view?docId=DicHist/uvaGenText/tei/DicHist4.xml;chunk.id=dv4-70;toc.depth=1;toc.id=dv4-70;brand=default The Wisdom of The Fool]'', Walter Kaiser illustrates that the varied names and words people have attributed to real fools in different societies when put altogether reveal the general characteristics of the wise fool as a literary construct: "empty-headed (''μάταιος'', ''inanis,'' fool), dull-witted (''μῶρος'', ''stultus,'' dolt, clown), feebleminded (''imbécile,'' dotard), and lacks understanding (ἄνοοσ, ἄφρων ''in-sipiens''); that he is different from normal men (idiot); that he is either inarticulate (''Tor'') or babbles incoherently (''fatuus'') and is given to boisterous merrymaking (''buffone''); that he does not recognize the codes of propriety (''ineptus'') and loves to mock others (''Narr''); that he acts like a child (νήπιος); and that he has a natural simplicity and innocence of heart (εὐήθης, natural, simpleton).<ref name=":0" />
While society reprimands violent maniacs, destined to be locked away in jails or asylums, the harmless fool often receives kindnesses and benefits from the social elite.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/25707836|title=Majnūn : the madman in medieval Islamic society|last=1942-|first=Dols, Michael W. (Michael Walters),|date=1992|publisher=Clarendon Press|others=Immisch, Diana E.|isbn=0198202210|location=Oxford|oclc=25707836}}</ref> Seemingly guided by nothing other than natural instinct, the fool is not expected to grasp [[social conventions]] and thus is left to enjoy relative freedom, particularly in his or her freedom of speech.<ref name=":0" /> This unusual power dynamic is famously demonstrated through [[Shakespearean fool#List of Shakespearean fools|the fool]] in [[Shakespeare]]'s ''[[King Lear]],''<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/931813845|title=The tragedy of King Lear|last=author.|first=Shakespeare, William, 1564-1616,|isbn=9781501118111|oclc=931813845}}</ref> who works in the royal court and remains the only character who Lear does not severely punish for speaking his mind about the king and his precarious situations. This ability to be reckless, honest, and free with language has greatly contributed to the wise fool's popularity in the literary imagination.
''To call a man a fool is not necessarily an insult, for the authentic life has frequently been pictured under the metaphor of the fool. In figures such as Socrates, Christ, and the Idiot of Dostoyevsky we see that foolishness and wisdom are not always what they seem to be.'' - [[Sam Keen]], Apology for Wonder<ref>{{cite book|author=Keen, Sam|title=Apology for Wonder |page=128}}</ref>
== History ==
=== Antiquity === The employment and occupation of the fool played a significant role in the ancient world. The Ancient Greek authors [[Xenophon]] and [[Athenaeus]] wrote of normal men hired to behave as insane fools and clowns while the Roman authors [[Lucian]] and [[Plautus]] left records of powerful Romans who housed deformed buffoons famous for their insolence and brazen madness.<ref name=":0" /> [[Plato]], through the guise of [[Socrates]], provides an early example of the wisdom of the fool in ''[[Republic (Plato)|The Republic]]'' through the figure of an escaped prisoner in [[Allegory of the Cave|The Allegory of the Cave]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/908430812|title=Republic|last=Plato.|date=2015|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=067499650X|oclc=908430812}}</ref> The escaped prisoner, part of a group imprisoned from birth, returns to free his fellow inmates but is regarded as a madman in his attempts to convince his shackled friends of a greater world beyond the cave. [[File:Socrates_Louvre.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Socrates_Louvre.jpg|thumb|347x347px|The wise fool of ancient Greece. ''Portrait of [[Socrates]] (''Roman artwork, 1st century, The Louvre Museum).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cartelfr.louvre.fr/cartelfr/visite?srv=car_not_frame&idNotice=923|title=Site officiel du musée du Louvre|website=cartelfr.louvre.fr|access-date=2018-11-04}}</ref>]] Numerous scholars have long regarded Socrates as the paramount wise fool of [[classical antiquity]].<ref name=":0" /> Through what would come be to branded as [[Socratic irony]], the philosopher was known to make fools of people who claimed to be wise by pretending to be an ignorant fool himself.<ref>Oxford English Dictionary under ''irony.''</ref> His name also bears a strong association with the [[I know that I know nothing|Socratic Paradox]], "I know that I know nothing," a statement that has come to frame him in the oxymoron of the ignorant knower. In Plato's [[Apology (Plato)|Apology]], this self admission of ignorance ultimately leads the [[Pythia|oracle at Delphi]] to claim there is no man with greater wisdom than Socrates.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/1050649303|title=Apology|last=Plato.|isbn=1504052137|oclc=1050649303}}</ref>
=== Medieval === The wise fool manifested most commonly throughout the Middle Ages as a religious figure in stories and poetry. During the [[Islamic Golden Age]] (approx. 750 - 1280 CE), an entire literary genre formed around reports about the "intelligent insane."<ref name=":12">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/25707836|title=Majnūn : the madman in medieval Islamic society|last=1942-|first=Dols, Michael W. (Michael Walters),|date=1992|publisher=Clarendon Press|others=Immisch, Diana E.|isbn=0198202210|location=Oxford|oclc=25707836}}</ref> One book in particular, ''Kitab Ugala al-majanin'', by an-Naysaburi, a muslim author from the [[Abbasid period|Abbasid Period]], recounts the lives of numerous men and women recognized during their lifetimes as 'wise fools.'<ref name=":12" /> Folkloric variations of madmen, lost between wisdom and folly, also appear throughout the period's most enduring classic, [[One Thousand and One Nights|The Thousand and One Nights]]. Buhlil the Madman, also known as the Lunatic of Kufa and Wise Buhlil, is often credited as the prototype for the wise fool across the Middle East.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/148646349|title=Fools are everywhere : the court jester around the world|last=K.|first=Otto, Beatrice|date=2001|publisher=Univ of Chicago Press|isbn=9780226640921|oclc=148646349}}</ref>
[[Holy fool|The fool for God's sake]] was a figure that appeared in both the Muslim and Christian world. Often wearing little to no clothes, this variant of the [[Foolishness for Christ|holy fool]] would forego all social customs and conventions and feign madness in order to be possessed with their creator's spirit.<ref name=":12" /> By the twelfth century in France, such feigning led to [[Feast of Fools|the Fête des Fous]] (Feast of Fools), a celebration in which clergy were allowed to behave as fools without inhibition or restraint.<ref name=":0" /> During [[Crusades|the Crusades]], Christ was recognized as a 'wise fool' figure through his childlike teachings that yet confounded the powerful and intellectual elite. Numerous other writers during this period would explore this theological paradox of the wise fool in Christ, sustaining the trope into the Renaissance.
=== Renaissance === [[File:The_praise_of_folly_Fleuron_T140366-21.png|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:The_praise_of_folly_Fleuron_T140366-21.png|thumb|''Erasmus and Stultitia, the Goddess of Folly, are joined through literature. Engraving by W. Kennet, late [[Bishop of Peterborough|Lord Bishop of Peterborough]]. Based on the designs of the painter [[Hans Holbein the Younger|Hans Holbeine]].''|287x287px]] The wise fool received tremendous popularity in the literary imagination during the [[Italian Renaissance|Italian]] and [[English Renaissance|English Renaissances]]. In Italian scholar Erasmus' ''[[In Praise of Folly|Moriae encomium]],'' written in 1509 and first published in 1511, the author portrays [[In Praise of Folly|Stultitia]], the goddess of folly, and a wise fool herself, who asks what it means to be a fool and puts forth a brazen argument praising folly and claiming that all people are fools of one kind or another.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/42855542|title=Living without philosophy : on narrative, rhetoric, and morality|last=1967-|first=Levine, Peter,|date=1998|publisher=State University of New York Press|isbn=0585062382|location=Albany, N.Y.|oclc=42855542}}</ref> According to scholar Walter Kaiser, Stultitia is "the foolish creation of the most learned man of his time, she is the literal embodiment of the word ''oxymoron,'' and in her idiotic wisdom she represents the finest flowering of that fusion of Italian humanistic thought and northern piety which has been called [[Christian humanism|Christian Humanism]]."<ref name=":0" />
At the same time, Shakespeare greatly helped popularize the wise fool in the English theater through incorporating the trope in a variety of characters throughout many of his plays.<ref name=":32">{{Cite web|url=https://www.bl.uk/shakespeare/articles/shakespeares-fools|title=Shakespeare's fools|website=The British Library|language=en|access-date=2018-10-09}}</ref> While Shakespeare's early plays largely portray the wise fool in comic terms as a buffoon, the later plays characterize the fool in a much more melancholic and contemplative light.<ref name=":32" /> For example, in ''[[King Lear]]''<ref name=":23">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/931813845|title=The tragedy of King Lear|last=author.|first=Shakespeare, William, 1564-1616,|isbn=9781501118111|oclc=931813845}}</ref>, the Fool becomes the only one capable of speaking truth to the King and often takes on the role of revealing life's tragic nature to those around him. For Shakespeare, the trope became so well-known that when [[Olivia (Twelfth Night)|Olivia]] says of the clown [[Feste]] in [[Twelfth Night]], "This fellow is wise enough to play the fool" (III.i.60), his audiences recognized it as a popular convention.<ref name=":0" />
Numerous other authors rendered interpretations of the wise fool across the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries from [[Hans Sachs]] to [[Michel de Montaigne|Montaigne]]. The image of the wise fool is as well found in numerous Renaissance artworks by a range of artists including [[Jan Brueghel the Elder|Breughel]], [[Hieronymus Bosch|Bosch]], and [[Hans Holbein the Younger|Holbein the Younger]].<ref name=":0" /> In Spain, Cervantes' novel [[Don Quixote]] exemplifies the world of the wise fool through both its title character and his companion, Sancho Panza.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Close|first=A. J.|date=1973|title=Sancho Panza: Wise Fool|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/3725864|journal=The Modern Language Review|volume=68|issue=2|pages=344–357|doi=10.2307/3725864}}</ref>
==Examples in modern literature and film==
[[A Song of Ice and Fire|Patchface]]
(from ''[[A Song of Ice and Fire]] /'' a fool to King [[Stannis Baratheon]] who was the only survivor of a shipwreck that killed Stannis' parents. As a result, he was apparently driven mad and makes seemingly nonsensical statements. However, his words seem to prophecy significant events in the series, such as the [[the Red Wedding|Red Wedding]].)<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/816446630|title=A song of ice and fire|last=R.|first=Martin, George R.|date=2011|publisher=Harper Voyager|isbn=9780007447862|oclc=816446630}}</ref>
[[Wonderful Fool|Gaston Bonaparte]]
(from The Japanese novelist [[Shusaku Endo]]'s 1959 novel '''[[Wonderful Fool]]''' / protagonist Gaston Bonaparte is portrayed as a relative of Napoleon Bonaparte who visits Japan. He bumbles his way through troubles by naively ignoring or not understanding a series of problems and attacks, but leaves his Japanese friends enlightened.) <ref>{{cite|last = Endo| first = Shusako| title = おバカさん Obaka san (Wonderful Fool)| publisher = Chuo| year = 1959|others = Wonderful Fool (Harpers 1974 translated by Francis Mathy| ref = none}}</ref>
[[The Big Lebowski|The Dude]]
(from [[Coen brothers|The Coen Brothers]]' film, ''The Big Lebowski'')<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Coen|first=Ethan|last2=Coen|first2=Joel|title=The Big Lebowski|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.5040/do-9780571343188-div-00000003|journal=The Big Lebowski|doi=10.5040/do-9780571343188-div-00000003}}</ref>
